DataElement.preferredDefinition: the reason or cause for a patient to end the follow-up visit schedule specified by the protocol.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the study follow-up during off-treatment.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Off-Treatment; the phase of a protocol during which a patient does not receive treatment.:A type of research study that tests how well new medical treatments or other interventions work in people.  Such studies test new methods of screening, prevention, diagnosis, or treatment of a disease.  The study may be carried out in a clinic or other medical facility.  Also called a clinical trial.

Concepts.definition: When a patient is not receiving therapy they are considered off treatment.  In clinical trials, a dosing schedule may require a patient to stop medication for a period of time, then resume, such as 28 days on and 7 days off.

Research conducted with human subjects or on material of human origin in which an investigator directly interacts with human subjects; includes development of new technologies, study of mechanisms of human diseases, therapy, clinical trials, epidemiologic, behavior, and health services research.

Property.preferredDefinition: Monitoring a person's health over time after treatment.  This includes keeping track of the health of people who participate in a clinical study or clinical trial for a period of time, both during the study and after the study ends.

Concepts.definition: The process by which information about the health status of an individual is obtained after a study has officially closed; an activity that continues something that has already begun or that repeats something that has already been done.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: justification for or explanation of the administration or cessation of therapy.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the reason or cause for a patient to end the follow-up visit schedule specified by the protocol.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The loss or lack of continuation of subject participation after a study has officially closed.

Concepts.definition: The loss or lack of continuation of subject participation after a study has officially closed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The absence of life or state of being dead.

Concepts.definition: The cessation of life.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

This method is also valuable in diagnosis of benign abnormal conditions of the breast such as fibroadenoma, mastitis, abscess, and cysts.: Caused by or resulting from.: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Far apart in space from a point of origin on the body.: To come back or to return.

The smallest natural number and quantity it denotes: a single entity, unit, or object.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.

A low voltage X-ray photograph of the breast generally done to detect breast cancer. This method is also valuable in diagnosis of benign abnormal conditions of the breast such as fibroadenoma, mastitis, abscess, and cysts.
Caused by or resulting from.
Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Enrollment Other Children's Oncology Group Clinical Study
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The act of registration, entering in a list, catalog, group, study; also, the number of subjects enrolled._Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned._An NCI-supported clinical cooperative group formed by the merger of the four national pediatric cancer research organizations: the Children's Cancer Group, the Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study Group, the National Wilms Tumor Study Group, and the Pediatric Oncology Group. The primary objective of the organization is to conduct clinical trials of new therapies for childhood and adolescent cancer. COG develops and coordinates clinical trials conducted at the 238 member institutions that include cancer centers of all major universities and teaching hospitals throughout the U.S. and Canada, as well as sites in Europe and Australia. COG members include over 5000 cancer researchers._Research conducted with human subjects or on material of human origin in which an investigator directly interacts with human subjects; includes development of new technologies, study of mechanisms of human diseases, therapy, clinical trials, epidemiologic, behavior, and health services research.

Concepts.definition: The act of registration, entering in a list, catalog, group, study; also, the number of subjects enrolled.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

An NCI-supported clinical cooperative group formed by the merger of the four national pediatric cancer research organizations: the Children's Cancer Group, the Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study Group, the National Wilms Tumor Study Group, and the Pediatric Oncology Group. The primary objective of the organization is to conduct clinical trials of new therapies for childhood and adolescent cancer. COG develops and coordinates clinical trials conducted at the 238 member institutions that include cancer centers of all major universities and teaching hospitals throughout the U.S. and Canada, as well as sites in Europe and Australia. COG members include over 5000 cancer researchers.

Research conducted with human subjects or on material of human origin in which an investigator directly interacts with human subjects; includes development of new technologies, study of mechanisms of human diseases, therapy, clinical trials, epidemiologic, behavior, and health services research.
